case_vignette: An 11-year-old man presents with fever and joint pain for the last 3 days. His mother says that he had a sore throat 3 weeks ago but did not seek medical care at that time. The family immigrated from the Middle East 3 years ago. The patient has no past medical history. The current illness started with a fever and a swollen right knee that was very painful. The following day, his knee improved but his left elbow became swollen and painful. While in the waiting room, his left knee is also becoming swollen and painful. Vital signs include: temperature 38.7°C (101.6°F), and blood pressure 110/80 mm Hg. On physical examination, the affected joints are swollen and very tender to touch, and there are circular areas of redness on his back and left forearm (as shown in the image).
question: Which  is needed to establish a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having a fever and pain in my joints for the last 3 days.
What is your age and sex?
I am an 11-year-old man.
Have you been taking any medications recently?
No, I haven't taken any medications recently.

Do you have a family history of autoimmune diseases?

**Final Diagnosis:** Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.

Note: While an elevated ESR can be a supportive finding in the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever, it is not sufficient on its own to make the diagnosis. A definitive diagnosis requires the presence of clinical evidence of heart involvement, joint involvement, and a positive serology for anti-streptolysin O or anti-deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) antibodies.
